i.d: Code indicating the issuing agency of a Government/Corporate bonds.
Internal system-created identifier for the mortgage-backed agency issuers.
Long name for the agencies issuing Government/Corporate bonds.
Descriptions for the agencies issuing Government/Corporate bonds.
Short description for the agencies issuing Government/Corporate bonds.
Short name for the agencies issuing Government/Corporate bonds.
First date information was announced pertaining to an upcoming auction of U.S. Treasury or agencies securities.
Unique Reuters system-assigned identifier for the security.
Code representing the status of the asset. Many status updates are performed programmatically.
Description of the Asset Status code.
Asset Status Effective Date.
Code representing the subclassification of the asset within the security type code.
Description of the Asset Sub Type Code.
Code representing the type of issuer selling the offered security.
Description of Asset Type.
First date when the asset was issued pertaining to an upcoming auction of U.S. Treasury or agencies securities.

Y/N flag indicating whether banks may deduct the interest expense for the purchase and holding of a municipal obligation. This field, in general, includes municipal securities under $10 million that were issued after August 6, 1986.
Bankruptcy Emerge Date.
Bankruptcy File Date.
Bankruptcy Flag.
Bankruptcy Type.
Bankruptcy Type Description.
Name of the borrower/originator of the bond.
OrgID of the borrower/originator of the bond.
Domicile country code of the borrower.
Domicile country name of the borrower.

Y/N flag indicating whether the issuer may redeem the security at its option before the scheduled maturity. This flag will be set to ‘Y’ for any true cash calls, for all others (i.e. tax call), this flag will be set to ‘N’.

Specific notation on callable bonds that give in a look the information on when is the first call date and what is the option frequency. Example: 5nc2 (1x) means: 5-Year maturity bond, 2-Year lockout, European callable (1x). The frequency of the option is defined as follow: European callable: (1x), American callable: (Cont), Quarterly: (Qtr), Semi Annual: (Semi), Annual: (Ann), Monthly: (Mth).
First date on or after which the asset can be called for refinancing purposes.
Code representing the type of call schedule.
Description of DS_CallType. See the call_type_cds table in the GCODES Database Viewer for a complete list of codes.
Tier in which the asset is classified for bank capital regulation purposes.
Code representing the asset class as assigned by the China Central Depository & Clearing Co., Ltd. (CDC).
Name representing the asset class as assigned by the China Central Depository & Clearing Co., Ltd. (CDC).
Contribution Root Code.
Contributor Source.
Code representing the country in which the security was issued.
Description of the Country Name.
Coupon Alternative Currency.
Coupon Alternative Currency Description.
Coupon payment applicable to the asset.
Description of the Coupon Class.
Short Description of the Coupon Class.
Code representing the currency in which the scheduled interest payments are made.
Description of the Coupon Currency.
Coupon Effective Date.
Abbreviated description of Coupon Frequency Description.
Code representing the frequency of coupon payments for the asset.
Description of the Coupone Frequency Code.
Pass-through coupon rate on a pool. Net coupon is equal to the gross coupon minus servicing fees.
Type of coupon payment applicable to the asset.
Description of Coupon Type.
Abbreviated description of Coupon Type.
Code representing the denomination of the security.
Currency Active Flag.
Currency Description.
Indicates when issue currency is denominated into a a pre-EYR leacy currency.
Description of Day Count Code.
Code representing the number of days in a month and the number of days assumed in a year. ACT signifies actual count.
Long Description of Day Count Code.
Number of business days after the completion of a trade during which the security is settled by the holder’s domestic clearinghouse.
Code indicating calendar used to determine settle date.
Unique DBS system-generated identifier for a security.
Debt Service Code.
Debt Service Code Description.
Debt Service Long Description.
Code representing the class of debt, including the type of collateral backing the debt.
Description of Debt Type.
Short Description of Debt Type.
Minimum multiples in which a bond can be held in the secondary market above the Minimum Denomination, stored in units of issuing currency.
Schedule of amounts in which the security may be purchased, expressed in face value, for example, 1,000, 10,000, 100,000.
Code representing the denomination type.
Description of Denomination Type.
Descriptive field containing items that identify the security, such as ticker, coupon, maturity date.
Bond name in Japanese (if available).
Thirty-character field that, when used with description, produces a detailed description of the asset.
Distribution Source.
Distribution Source Description.
Domicile Name.
Current rating assigned by Dominion Bond Rating Service Limited.
Date on which a new rating is assigned to the offered security by Dominion Bond Rating Service Limited.
Code representing the generic calendar position of the exdividend date. Exdividend is the interval between the announcement and the payment of the next dividend.
Ex-dividend rule.
Integer used with the exdividend calendar code. For example, if the dividend is paid on the 30th calendar day of the month, 30 would show in this field.
Executable Quote Flag.
Extended Schedule Flag.
Principal amount of the new security issued.
Total face amount of the security currently outstanding. For Treasuries, this is the total amount outstanding, not the amount outstanding public.
Effective date of the current outstanding amount expressed in the currency of the issue.
Firm to which the issuer belongs. System supplied issuers have the firm identifier for Reuters. User supplied issuers have the firm identifier of the user.

Date of the first coupon for the asset if the first coupon date does not fall within the regular payment cycle of the asset. Used to calculate long/short first payment amount for the purposes of cash-flow determination.
Fitchs Rank.
Current Fitch’s published or announced rating.
Effective date for DS_FitchsRating.
Fitchs SP Equivalent Rank.
Index used in the reset calculation for the bond (for example, the 3-month US LIBOR).
The maximum interest rate increase limitation per interest adjustment.
Float Life Floor.

Index coefficient by which index rate is multiplied when calculating the current interest rate on a floating rate index. The floater interest rate is calculated as: interest rate = float multiplier * index rate + float offset.
Increment added to the current interest rate calculation on a floating rate index.
Maximum interest rate increase limitation per interest adjustment.
Minimum interest rate decrease limitation per interest adjustment.
Government Bond Type.
Government Bond Type Description.

A Y/N flag indicating whether the bond is a green bond. Green bonds are a fixed income product that offers investors the opportunity to participate in the financing of large sustainable energy green' projects that help mitigate climate change and help countries adapt to the effects of climate changes.
Two-digit code representing the country in which the asset was issued.
Reuters Instrument Code (RIC) for the index.
Code identifying the industry of the issuer.
Description of Industry Sector.
Code representing a further breakdown of the industry of the issuer.
Industry Sub Sector Description.
A y/n flag indicating whether the security’s principal outstanding is linked to fluctuations in an inflation index, such as the consumer price index.
Instrument Type.
Instrument Type Description.
Instrument Type Short Description.
Insured CUSIP Flag.
Interest Collateral Description.
Interest Collateral Type.
Segment for which a specific set of interest terms are contained. A new leg number is added each time the key terms of the security change.
Code indicating the security’s asset status.
Y/N flag identifying the asset as a current benchmark security.
Y/N flag indicating whether the bond is callable.
Y/N flag indicating whether the underlying mortgages of a pool can be converted from floating to fixed-rate loans.

A y/n flag indicating whether the security may be exchanged or converted into another type of security from the issuer (for example, common stock). For mortgage pools, this flag indicates whether the underlying mortgages of a pool can be converted from floating to fixed-rate loans.
Y/N flag indicating whether the bond is currently callable. Currently callable bonds have already passed their first call date.
Y/N flag indicating whether an issue is eligible to be registered and exchanged through the Depository Trust Company.
Y/N flag indicating whether the method for calculating the coupon payment for the asset is dated from the maturity date or the first coupon date, if either date falls on the last day of the month.
Is EU Savings Gov Related.
Is EU Savings Swiss Exempt.
Is EU Savings Tapped.
Is EU Savings Taxed.
Y/N flag indicating whether exchange listings information is available for the bond.
Y/N flag indicating whether the bond has a floating rate coupon.

Y/N flag indicating whether there is a third party guarantee or, in some rare instances, a self-guarantee in effect as to the timely payment of interest and principal applicable to the asset at anytime during the asset's term.
Is Index Linked Interest.
Is Index Linked Principal.
Y/N flag indicating whether the security is a medium term note.
Is Multi Step Float.
Code representing the ISO denomination of the security.
ISO Currency Description.
Code representing the ISO denomination of the security.
Y/N flag indicating whether the security is an original issue discount.
ISO Short Country Code.
Y/N flag indicating whether the security has a specified maturity date.
Y/N flag indicating whether the bond selected for redemption must be chosen on a pro-rata basis or in a lottery.
Y/N flag indicating whether put terms and put schedules apply to the asset.
Is Quote Clean.
Y/N flag indicating whether the bond has a sinking fund.
Y/N flag indicating whether the bond qualifies as “straight”, meaning the bond is not callable, putable, convertible, or issued in more than one currency.
Date of issuance of the asset (for example, the date of initial settlement).
Price to the public of an issue on an original issue date.
Current country of the party's principal executive offices.
Issuer Capital Name.
Issuer Country.
Issuer Country Name.
Issuer Country Of Incorporation.
Long name of the company.
Unique Reuters system-assigned identifier for the issuer.
International Standard Organization (ISO) country name for the country in which the asset was issued. Primarily, the country of residence of the issuer.
Three-digit code representing the country in which the asset was issued.
Credit rating assignment from external source.
Start date for which the credit rating is in effect.
Code indicating the credit rating rank.
Name of the company.
Name of the company in Japanese (if available).
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier used to link instruments to an organization. Also used to integrate Reuters DataScope Fixed Income FTP with DataScope Equity FTP for issue-level data.
Short name of the company.
Credit rating assignment from external source.
Start date for which the credit rating is in effect.
Code indicating the credit rating rank.
Credit rating assignment from external source.
Start date for which the credit rating is in effect.
Code indicating the credit rating rank.
Last date on which asset structure information was changed in the system.
Last coupon or dividend payment date prior to maturity of the asset. Used to calculate long/short last payment amount for cash-flow determination or accrued interest.
Date of the latest call start.
Date of the latest put start.
Date corresponding to the current rating assigned to the security by a rating agency.
Location code for the security.
Description of the Location code.
Long name of the issuer.
Reuters Instrument Code (RIC) of the benchmark security at maturity.

Date the asset pays the remaining total principal amount to the holder in a redemption transaction. For an extendible security, the maturity date will change on each extend date from the current extend date to the next extend date.
Integer value identifying the redemption event that was assumed in calculating cash flows.
Sink speed used in the cash-flow assumptions. Possible values include: none, slowest, or fastest. Used for sinking fund bonds.
Code indicating how income is paid upon maturity or expiration of the instrument.
Description of Maturity Type codes.
Code representing a bond's lowest rating in the Standard & Poor's equivalent, or a bond's status if it is not active.
A y/n flag indicating if Moody reported credit support or enhancements on the security.
Forecasts the possible change in credit rating for the asset.
Effective date for Moody's Credit Watch.
Description of Moody's Credit Watch.
Code indicating the Moody’s Credit Watch rank.
Moody's Rank.
Current Moody’s published or announced rating.
Date the Moody’s rating was effective for the asset.
Moodys SP Equivalent Rank.
Code indicating the formula, including day count and compounding conventions, used for price/yield calculations.
Description of Native Yield Type codes.
Next date the issuer can call the bond before maturity. If the bond is callable now, the next call date is the date on which the call price changes.
Redemption price on the next scheduled call date.
Next Mandatory Tender Date.
Date the next coupon payment will be made.
Date of the next scheduled put.
Redemption price on the next scheduled put date.
Scheduled sinking fund amount on the next scheduled sinking fund date.
Next scheduled date the issuer can or must make a sinking fund redemption.
Code representing the nature of the registration.
Description of Offering Type codes.
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier used to link instruments related to an organization. It also integrates DataScope Fixed Income FTP with DataScope Equity FTP for issuer-level data.
Total principal amount of the securities offered as given on the front cover of the prospectus.
Original Average Life.
Code representing the currency in which the currency was first issued.
Nominal (original) spread, in basis points, over the Treasury benchmark when the bond was issued.

Calculation that determines rate of the return an investor will receive if a long-term, interest-bearing investment is held to its maturity date. The calculation formula includes purchase price, redemption value, time to maturity, coupon yield, and the time between interest payments. For floating rate securities, the initial coupon rate is used in the calculation.
Owner trustee name for the bond issue.
Code identifying the industry of the original immediate parent.
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier for the issuer's original immediate parent.
Name of the issuer's original immediate parent company.

Unique Reuters system-generated identifier used to facilitate the linkage of instruments related to an organization. It also facilitates the integration of DataScope FI FTP with DataScope Equity FTP for issuer level data.
Long name of the issuer's original immediate parent company.
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier used to link instruments related to an organization. It also integrates DataScope Fixed Income FTP with DataScope Equity FTP for issuer-level data.
Industry of the issuer's original immediate parent company as defined by Standard and Poor’s.
Parent Immed SP Industry Description.
Code used to identify the common stock by the market exchange upon which the issuer's original immediate parent is traded.
Code identifying the industry of the issuer’s parent company.
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier for the issuer's parent company.
Name of the issuer’s parent company.
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier used to link instruments related to an organization. It also integrates DataScope Fixed Income FTP with DataScope Equity FTP for issuer-level data.
Long name of the issuer’s parent company as it appears on the front cover of the prospectus.
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier used to link instruments related to an organization. It also integrates DataScope Fixed Income FTP with DataScope Equity FTP for issuer-level data.
Unique Reuters system-generated identifier for a party.
Short name of the parent company.
Current long name of the issuer of the offered security.
Parent SP Industry.
Industry of the issuer’s parent company as defined by Standard and Poor’s.
Code used to identify the common stock by the market or exchange upon which the issuer’s parent company is traded.
Paying agent name for the bond issue.
Flag indicating whether the bond pays-in-kind (other bonds) instead of cash.
Y/N flag indicating a system of payment whereby part of the determined price for a new issue is paid, with the remainder being settled in installments on specified dates.
Preferred RIC.
Code representing the numeric format in which prices are quoted.
Code identifying the price quote method (c.f. EJV.C.PriceQuoteMethodDescription field for the code meaning.).
Description of the code identifying the price quote method (c.f. EJV.C.PriceQuoteMethod field for code).

Code representing the rounding factor, or number of decimals retained when calculating a price given a yield. For codes, K, M, D, F means that the price is respectively rounded down to the 2, 3, 4, 6 decimal places. For numbers, the price is rounded near to this number in term of decimal places.
Principal Alternative Currency.
Principal Alternative Currency Description.
Principal Collateral Description.
Principal Collateral Type.
Code indicating the currency in which principal payments are made.
Principal Currency Description.
Y/N flag indicating whether the security is issued by private placement. A private placement does not have to be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, as a public offering does.
Program Type.

Program Type Short Description.
Name of the project for which the municipal offering was made.
Prospectus Approval Date.
Code representing the registrant's planned use of its proceeds from the offering.

Code indicating the global region.

RTFIUS Eligibility Flag.
Code representing the type of foreign bond. Foreign bonds are issued on the domestic capital market by a foreign borrower and denominated in the domestic currency.

Seniority Type.

Seniority Type Short Description.
Unique name to identify the deal from the issuer.
Short name for the issuer.
Industry of the issuer based on the Bureau of the Budget Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) code. Structure uses the standard four-digit SIC.
Code that narrowly defines the sovereign entity.
Description of Sovereign Class codes.
Code representing a possible change in the credit rating for a security.
Date the issue was placed on credit watch by Standard and Poor’s.
Description of DS_SPCreditWatch codes.
Code indicating the Standard and Poor’s Credit Watch rank.
Company’s main industry or line of business as defined by Standard and Poor’s.
General description of the company’s industry as provided by Standard and Poor’s.
Number specifying a more detailed breakout of the company’s industry.
Subdescription of the industry’s main line of business.
Current Standard and Poor’s published or announced rank for the security.
Current Standard and Poor’s published or announced rating for the security.
Date the rating was effective for the asset.
SP SP Equivalent Rank.
Equivalent yield type to be used for comparison of yields across security types.
Description of the yield type code used to indicate standard yield convention, which is the yield generally used when quoting yields for the bond.
Code indicating whether the municipal bond is tax exempt or subject to alternative minimum tax.
Tax Status Description.

Equity ticker for the issuer of the asset. NYSE ticker is used if one exists. If an asset has more than one ticker, NYSE is recognized by Reuters as the ticker for the asset. If there is no NYSE symbol, Thomson Reuters will use another exchange symbol or assign an internal ticker.
Code indicating the trace eligibility of a security.
TRACE Eligible Description.
Underlying Registered CUSIP.
Name of the curve used to calculate the valuations data.
Code identifying from where the valuation information for the security comes.
Price source used to calculate derived values. Defaults to EJV.
Code representing the values that describe market rules for the setting of a valuation date, usually with respect to a trade or settlement date.
Code representing the vendor who provides the rate or index from the original source to Thomson Reuters.
Vendor Name.
Y/N flag indicating whether warrants were attached to the bond at issue.
Prepayment model used to compute the worst cash flows for the current security.
Last date principal is paid by the tranche when using the prepayment assumptions to compute the worst cash flows Calculated for CMOs only.
Date Worst Redem Event occurs. Date and event are determined by finding the circumstances that result in the lowest yield.
Value identifying whether the bond is assumed to be put, called, or matured on Worst Redem Date.
Integer value identifying the redemption event that was assumed for the computation of the worst cash flows.
Price as a percentage of par at which the security is assumed to be put, called, or matured on Worst Redem Date.
Number of years to Worst Redem Date.
Y/N flag indicating whether secondary market prices include (dirty) or exclude (clean) accrued interest.
Code representing the yield type.
Price Quote Base Value.
Description of Yield Type.
Details of the formula used to calculate the new rate of interest. Includes the algorithm used to calculate the new reset rate.
The formula used to calculate the new principal balance. Primarily, used for Treasury Inflation Protected Securities (TIPS).
List of the real time RICs for bonds.
A y/n flag indicating if S&P reported credit support or enhancements on the security.
Indicator representing eligibility for Euro system monetary policy operations.
A y/n flag indicating whether the security is eligible for repo transactions with the Central Bank indicated in EJV.C.RepoEligibleWith.
Central Bank name where a repo transaction can be carried with the security.
A y/n flag indicating whether Thomson Reuters has a prospectus for this security on file.
Depository name appointed to issue receipts for securities and hold such securities in deposit.
Code representing the Depository appointed to issue receipts for securities and hold such securities in deposit.
Country name where the sponsor of the SPV is domiciled.
Code representing the country where the sponsor of the SPV is domiciled.
The non-annual coupon rate. This is used primarily for Italian bonds.
A yes/no flag identifying a bond with a conversion option or write down feature linked to the issuers Tier 1 debt/capital ratio.
A y/n flag indicating if the bond carries a write down feature
The capital ratio (in percent) required to trigger the write-down of the security.
A y/n flag indicating whether the Contingent Capital bond has a write-up feature. This provision offers the possibility of a write-up if the bank restores its financial health.
Field shows the type of trigger potentially causing the write down.
Field shows the type of write down.
A y/n flag indicating whether a security is CRD compliant.
A y/n flag indicating whether a security is UCITS compliant.
The capital ratio (in percent) required to be met to trigger conversion of a CoCo issue.

A Y/N flag identifying a Contingen Capital bond.Contingent Capital bonds (CoCos) are hybrid capital securities which can absorb losses when the capital ratio of the issuing entity falls below a certain level.
Type of Contingent Capital bond. The field returns 'Write Down' or 'Equity Conversion' which represent different types of loss absorption mechanism.
The capital ratio (in percent) required to trigger the loss absorption mechanism.
Type of the trigger potentially causing the write down. The following options are available: Mechanical, Discretionary, Mechanical or Discretionary
Field indicates whether the principal writedown of a CoCo bond is full, partial or both.
A Y/N flag indicating whether the Contingent Capital bond has a write-up feature. This provision offers the possibility of a write-up if the bank restores its financial health.
A Y/N flag indicating whether a coupon payment can be deferred.
A Y/N flag indicating whether a coupon payment is accumulative.
Unique Thomson Reuters system-generated identifier used to link instruments to an organization. (Can be used as input code to return content on the guarantor)
Indicates the liable entity in case of borrower default.
Type of guarantor who has guaranteed the security.

Code representing the type of guarantor who has guaranteed the security. Here is the available codes list with description: BG: Bank Guarantee; GA: Government Agency; GAPG: Government Agency, Parent Guarantee; GG: Government Guarantee; GGPG: Government Guarantee, Parent Guarantee; MG: Municipality Guarantee; OTH: Other; PG: Parent Guarantee; PGBG: Parent Guarantee, Bank Guarantee; PGMG: State (Municipality) Guarantee, Parent Guarantee; SPG: Subordinated Parent Guarantee.
The country name of the guarantor.
The country code of the guarantor.
Date on which the enhancement credit becomes effective.
Last date for which the credit enhancement is effective.

It retrieves the algebraic formula that determines the coupon for an index-linked bond, the date from which the formula becomes effective, and the condition (if there is one) that the formula depends on.
Boolean flag indicating whether the bond has a bullet redemption.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have an extendible feature.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that are Medium-Term Notes.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds offers a refund.
Reversed Convertible.
The next date on which there can be any change in the call, put, or extend price.
Date of redenomination (restatement of outstanding national currency debt) of an issue into euros.
The next specified date on which the issuer can exercise his put option.
Displays the minimum number of days before the put date the bond holder must notify the issuer that the bond will be redeemed.
Indicates when the put option can be exercised.
For bonds that have an initial period of protection against refunding at a lower interest cost, the refund date is the first date the bond can be refunded.

The price an issuer pays when he is refunding an outstanding bond. (A refunding occurs when the issuer calls an outstanding bond and funds the call with proceeds raised by issuing a new bond, typically at a lower interest cost.).
Description of the type of the issue's redemption, e.g. Sinking Fund.
Indicates whether early or special redemption is allowed.
Method for determining value paid at maturity.
Retrieves a set of text strings that define the yield method conventions for the bond in Adfin terms. The output is 4 separate sub-components in the XML: METHOD, DAYCOUNT, COMPOUND, YLDTYPE.
The benchmark when the bond was originally issued.
The benchmark if the bond will be redeemed at its original maturity date.
The benchmark if the bond will be redeemed at its next redemption date.
Flag indicating whether the bond has a bullet redemption.
Yield Method Code.
Yield Method-Calc Convention Combine.
Coupon Type Code description.
Retrieves the coupon payment type of the bond (Fixed, FRN, Indexed FRN, Indexed Fixed, Multi-Coupon, Interest At Maturity, Defer Interest, Defer Discount, Zero, Annuity, Capitalised, None).
Specifies the method of handling interest accrual dates (not necessarily payment dates) that fall on a weekend, or on a holiday, as defined by the business center.
Flag indicating whether the issue is extendible.
Frequency Code description.
A two character code indicating the number of times in a calendar year that coupon payments are distributed.
Code indicating coupon reset frequency for a floating rate note.

This field serves two purposes: if the date is in the future, it represents the expected effective date that the security will adopt the indicated common EMU market convention; otherwise, it represents the actual effective date from which the security was.

Place whose business days are used in determining the reset date (accrual end date). Contrary to the holiday code, which affects the settlement date of the security, the Business Center affects the reset date of the security.
The value of the base index when the bond was issued.
Coupon frequency for an index-linked bond.
Name of the underlying index to which a floating rate note is indexed, e.g. LIUSD6M for 6 month USD Libor.
Date of next scheduled change in coupon rate.
New coupon rate effective on the next scheduled change date.
Flag indicating whether a bond is a Medium-Term Note.
The residual euro value of an issue that remains after renominalisation of the issue into the maximum number of round lots. Odd lots could be redeemed for cash or repackaged as separate bonds.
The date on which an issuer redeems odd lot amounts for cash or repackaged bonds.
It retrieves the date and amount of instalment payments on the partial payment bond (=a bond that is both issued in instalments and paid for in instalments prior to the first coupon date).
This value indicates the divisor of a price. Typically this value is a 100, however for some Turkish bonds the value is 100,000 because such bonds are quoted in nominal terms.
Specifies how the trustee determines which bonds are redeemed for a sinking fund payment.
The next specified date on which the issuer can exercise his call option.
Displays the minimum number of days before the call date the issuer must notify the holder that the bond will be called.
Indicates when the call option can be exercised.
Rule to determine the value date with respect to settlement or trade date. The value date is used to calculate accrued interest.
The next specified price that the issuer has to pay in the event that he decides to exercise his call option.
The next specified price at which the bondholder has the option to sell the bond back to the issuer.
The next price at which the principal is retired.
The next sinking fund principal amount that the issuer must redeem, as specified in the bond documentation (prospectus).
The next total principal amount (required amount plus maximum optional additional amount) that the bond documentation allows the issuer to redeem.
The redemption extend.
The coupon reset history for a floating rate bond.
The amount of the last instalment payment on the partial payment bond.
The conditions of the base index when the bond was issued.
The formula of the base index when the bond was issued.
The base index frequency.
The coupon reset frequency.
The coupon reset frequency code.
The floating rate note frequency.
The floating rate note incremental cap.
The floating rate note incremental floor.
The floating rate note absolute cap.
The floating rate note absolute floor.
The conditions of the coupon formula for a floating rate note.
The algebraic formula that determines the coupon form a floating rate note.
The BOT (Italian Treasury Bill) maturity date.
The BOT (Italian Treasury Bill) price.
The BOT (Italian Treasury Bill) yield.
The Index RIC associated to the instrument or Quote.
Bond Structure Error.

Retrieves the BondStructure of a bond regardless of the bond type (FRN, Index-linked or Bond). Warning! The data returned by this field may be spread over multiple cells. Users must plan an appropriate number of empty cells.
ADF Bond Structuren.
The (annualized) rate of interest paid by the bond in the current period.
Name of the underlying index to which a floating rate note is indexed, e.g. LIUSD6M for 6 month USD Libor.
The spread to the index that determines a floating rate notes coupon.
The date on which the bond will be redeemed completely.
Rate Structure Error.
Retrieves the RateStructure of an instrument.
String giving the rule used by Adfin to determine a settlement date using the BdSettle function.
Structure Error.

Retrieves a string made up with a series of parameters. Depending on the bond type, this parameter is either the bond structure for vanilla bonds, ILStructure for Index Linked bonds or FRN structure for FRN bonds.
ADF Structuren.
Indicator to determine the Structure that should be used with the bond.
Code assigned by a rating agency indicating the investment quality of the offered security.
Code representing the rating rank.
Rating Source Type Description.
Code assigned by the rating agency indicating the investment quality of the offered security, converted into the S&P rating scheme
Rating SP Equivalent Rank.
Last date the rating was verified.
Boolean flag indicating if this rating is a preliminary rating.
Identify the credit ratings endorsed by a locally registered rating agency. The EU requires ratings assigned outside of the EU be endorsed by a locally registered rating agency.
Boolean flag indicating whether the rating is unsolicited.
Rating source name which publish the credit rating.
Date when the credit rating has been published by the credit rating agency.

This field is used to indicate the regulatory qualifier required by EU Regulation to denote the ratings of structured finance instruments. It is also used to save other specific suffixes assigned by different rating agencies. For example, '(emr)' or '(mmf)' for Fitch ratings. The '(sf)' symbol indicates that the security is a structured finance instrument. It is requested by EU to append the suffix to the rating codes. Note: A space needs to be included when appending the qualifier to the rating. For example, AAA (sf), mxAAA (sf), AAA (sf)/NEG. In addition to the '(sf)' indicator, Fitch has also implemented two new ratings suffixes: '(mmf)' and '(emr)' to increase the transparency to what the rating addresses. For example, '(emr)' denotes embedded risk. This is present in directly issued structured notes where the embedded risk is the credit risk of a third party or of a basket of third parties. The suffix '(mmf)' indicates that this rating is applicable for a Money Market Fund.
Identify the credit ratings endorsed by a locally registered rating agency. The EU requires ratings assigned outside of the EU be endorsed by a locally registered rating agency.
Code of the rating source which publish the credit rating.
First date on which the bond is placed under a special credit evaluation.
Last date on which an issue is under a special credit evaluation by a given rating agency.
Rating source which place under credit evaluation the bond.
Code representing a possible change in the credit rating for a security.
Description of the code representing a possible change in the credit rating for a security.
Code representing the outlook trend for a security.
Specifies the date on which the outlook was effective.
Description representing the outlook trend for a security.
End date of the outlook time period for a security.
Rating agency name used for outlook.
Descriptive information regarding the terms and conditions not captured in collection items.
Descriptive information regarding the terms and conditions not captured in collection items.
Date the accrual of interest begins for the bond.
Amount of interest that the buyer owes the seller of the security on the settlement date.
Coupon divided by price, expressed as a percent.
Prepayment speed that results in the same average life as that computed using Maturity Prepay Model.
Last date principal is paid by the tranche under the given prepayment assumptions. Calculated for CMOs only.
First date principal is paid by the tranche under the given prepayment assumptions. Calculated for CMOs only.
Maturity date for governments and corporates. NULL for mortgages and CMOs.
Maturity for corporates and governments. NULL for mortgages and CMOs.
Price as a percentage of par at maturity.
Number of years from the settlement date to the maturity date.
Number of days used to calculate accrued interest for the given settlement date.
Next date the payment will be reset.
Next date the rate will be reset.
Flat price for the security.
Ask Price.
Ask Yield.
Short name for the benchmark curve.
Asset ID or CUSIP for the benchmark used in the pricing recipe.
Short name for the benchmark.
Time to maturity for the benchmark security used in pricing the given security.
Identifies the pricing benchmark type: an on-the-run Treasury, a benchmark derived from the interpolated curve or a specific security.
Code representing the benchmark type.
Value assigned to the benchmark to price the security. Can be yield-based or price-based.
Difference between the bid and ask prices for the security.
Bid Price.
Bid Yield.
Closing price assigned to the security by the Reuters Evaluations Desk. Generally, the same as Price.
Closing yield assigned to the security by the Reuters Evaluations Desk. Generally, the same as Yield to Worst.
Code identifying from where the pricing information for the security comes.
Mean price of the security.
Mean yield of the security.
Code representing the method used to price the security.
Value assigned to the security based on the method used to price the security.
Pricing Mid Price.
Pricing Mid Yield.
Date for the redemption event used in the pricing recipe.
Redemption event chosen, given the pricing recipe. Possible values include called, put, or traded to maturity.
Redemption type used to determine the redemption event used in the pricing.
Sink speed assumption used in the pricing recipe. Possible values include none, slowest, or fastest.
Source of the closing price. Defaults to EJV.
Trade date used to price the security.
Pricing Trading Status.
Degree to which the security's price or yield is expected to rise or fall sharply within a short-term period.
Years to redemption for the redemption date used in the pricing recipe.
Yield convention used for stating DS_PricingClosingYield for example, corporate bond yield, treasury yield, or mortgage yield.
Date cash payments for purchases are due and accrued interest and price/yield relationships are computed.
Settlement Date Convention.
Date for which the record applies.

Average life of the security, calculated with the cash-flow assumption that corporate and government securities trade to maturity. For mortgage backed securities, Reuters applies consensus prepayment speeds.
As-of-date for Maturity Average Life.
Convexity of the security. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Average Life. Convexity measures the degree of curvature of the price/yield curve at the given price.
Approximate change in price for a one basis point change in corporate bond equivalent yield. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions that corporate and government securities trade to maturity.
Measure of interest rate risk. Calculated by taking a present value weighted average of the time until receipt of cash flows using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Average Life.
Measure of interest rate risk. Represents the percentage change in value per unit shift in the yield curve. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Average Life.
On-the-run issue that is nearest to Maturity Average Life.
Difference between the corporate bond equivalent yield and the yield on the nearest on-the-run Treasury. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Average Life.
Term to maturity (in years) to Maturity Corp OTR Point.
Yield on the on-the-run issue identified by Maturity Corp OTR Point.

Spread computed by taking the difference between the yield on the bond and the corresponding yield on the Treasury curve. This differs from the OTR spread in that the Treasury yield is interpolated from the two on-the-run issues that bracket the average life rather than set equal to the nearest on-the-run issue. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Corp OTR Point.
Corporate bond equivalent cash-flow yield using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Average Life.

Spread over the index rate that results in discount rates that produce a present value of discounted cash flows equal to the settlement price. Used to analyze floating rate securities. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Average Life.
Yield on a discount security. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Maturity Average Life.
Basis point spread to the Treasury spot curve used to discount the cash flows to maturity.
Difference between the yield to maturity of the bond and the yield to maturity of the nearest on-the-run Treasury security.
Number of years to maturity of the on-the-run Treasury that is nearest to the maturity of the bond being analyzed.
Yield to maturity of the on-the-run Treasury used for the calculation of the OTR spread.
Yield to maturity expressed in terms that are standard for the current security.

Average life computed using cash-flow assumptions that represent expected outcome. For mortgage-backed securities, Reuters applies consensus prepayment speeds. For corporates and governments, Reuters determines the worst sinking fund and call and the best put.
Worst Average Life As-of-Date.
Convexity calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life. Convexity measures the degree of curvature of the price/yield curve at the given price.
Change in price for a security given a one basis point change in the corporate bond equivalent yield. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.

Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life. Macaulay duration is a measure of interest rate risk and is calculated by taking a present value weighted average of the time until receipt of cash flows.
Measure of interest rate risk. Expressed as the percentage change in value per unit shift in the yield curve. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
On-the-run issue nearest to the Worst Average Life.
Difference between the corporate bond equivalent yield and the yield on the nearest on-the-run Treasury. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Term to maturity in years to Worst Corp OTR Point.
Yield on the on-the-run issue identified by Worst Corp OTR Point.

Computed by taking the difference between the yield on the bond and the corresponding yield of the Treasury curve. This differs from the OTR spread in that the Treasury yield is interpolated from the two on-the-run issues that bracket the average life, rather than set equal to the nearest on-the-run issue. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Corporate bond equivalent cash-flow yield using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.

Spread over the index rate that results in discount rates that produce a present value of discounted cash flows equal to the settlement price. Used to analyze floating rate securities. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Method of describing the yield on a discount security. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Sink speed used in the cash-flow assumptions. Possible values include: none, slowest, or fastest. Used for sinking fund bonds.
Basis point spread to the Treasury spot curve that, when used to discount the worst cash flows, results in the value of the security.
Difference between the yield-to-worst call on the bond and the yield on the nearest on-the-run Treasury security.
The number of years to maturity of the on-the-run treasury that is nearest in term to the worst call on the bond being analyzed.
Yield-to-worst of the on-the-run Treasury used for the calculation of the OTR Spread.
Yield on the bond expressed as the standard form for the security. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Standard deviation of the average life derived from each of the interest rate paths in the Monte Carlo option simulation. A measure of average life risk.
Calculated mean average life of each path in the option adjusted spread.
Measure of the curvature of the price-yield relationship of a fixed income security, calculated using a model that accounts for any embedded options.
Price of the security, assuming constant option-adjusted spread, when the term structure is shifted down 25-basis points.

Modified duration of a security calculated using an option-based model that accounts for embedded options. The OA duration indicates how cash flows change when interest rates change. Also known as “rate duration” and “OA duration.”.
DV01 of a security, calculated from an option-based model that accounts for any embedded options.
Difference in basis points between the option-adjusted spread calculated with Reuters default volatility assumptions and the option-adjusted spread calculated with zero volatility.
Dollar value of the security’s embedded options.
Standard deviation of the prices derived from each of the interest rate paths in the Monte Carlo option simulation. A measure of price risk.
Measure of the security’s extra return over the return of a comparable Treasury security after accounting for any embedded options.

Spread convexity is the convexity with respect to a change in the option adjusted spread. Calculation is identical to the option adjusted convexity except that Reuters shifts OAS rather than term structure.

Spread duration is the duration with respect to a change in the option adjusted spread. Calculation is identical to the option adjusted duration except that Reuters shifts OAS rather than term structure.
Price of the security, assuming constant option-adjusted spread, when the term structure is shifted up 25-basis points.
Yield to maturity adjusted for the value of embedded options.

Identical to Option Adjusted Spread, but with the assumption of zero volatility. The difference between Option Adjusted Spread and Option Adjusted Zero Vol Spread can be viewed as the cost in basis points of the imbedded options.
Amount outstanding for the issue as of the end of the prior month.
Return arising from interest payments since the end of the prior month.
Fitch rating as of the end of the prior month.
Change in Fitch rating between the end of the prior month and yesterday’s close. The value is expressed as an integer representing the increase or decrease in rating scores.
Moody’s rating as of the end of the prior month.
Change in Moody’s rating between the end of the prior month and yesterday’s close. The value is expressed as an integer representing the increase or decrease in rating scores.
Option-adjusted duration for the security as of the end of the prior month.
Option-adjusted spread on the security as of the end of the prior month.
Change in option-adjusted spread between the end of the prior month and yesterday’s close.
Price of the security at the end of the prior month.
Change in price between the end of the prior month and yesterday’s close.
Return on the security that arises from a change in price since the end of the prior month.
Return on principal payments received by the investors since the end of the prior month. Principal payments can come from sinking funds, calls, scheduled principal payouts, or prepayments.
Return arising from the earned interest on all the cash flows paid out and reinvested since the end of the prior month.
Standard and Poor’s rating at the end of the prior month.
Change in Standard and Poor’s rating between the end of the prior month and yesterday’s close. Expressed as an integer representing the increase or decrease in rating scores.
Total cash-flow payments made to investors since the end of the prior month. Total cash flow includes accrued interest, coupon income, principal payments, and interest on reinvested cash flows.

Measure of interest risk representing the percentage change in value per unit shift in the yield curve as of the end of the prior month. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Corporate bond equivalent cash-flow yield as of the end of the prior month. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Change in corporate bond equivalent cash-flow yield between the end of the prior month and yesterday’s close. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Number of years to Worst Redemption Date as of the end of the prior month.
Interest return on the security since the previous business day.
Change in Fitch’s rating since the previous business day. Expressed as an integer representing the increase or decrease in rating scores.
Change in Moody’s rating since the previous business day. Expressed as an integer representing the increase or decrease in rating scores.
Value of the option-adjusted spread at the close of the previous business day.
Change in option-adjusted spread since the previous business day.
Price of the security at the close of the previous business day.
Change in the price of the security since the close of the previous business day.
Return on the security since the close of the previous business day due to a change in price.
Return on the security since the close of the previous business day that is due to return of principal. Can come from sinking funds, calls, scheduled principal payouts, or prepayments.
Reinvestment return since the previous business day. Always equal to zero and only included for completeness.
Change in Standard and Poor’s rating from the previous business day. Expressed as an integer representing the increase or decrease in rating scores.
Total cash-flow payments made to investors since the close of the previous business day. Includes accrued interest, coupon income, principal payments, and interest on reinvested cash flows.
Corporate bond equivalent cash-flow yield as of the close of the previous business day. Calculated using the cash-flow assumptions described in Worst Average Life.
Change in Worst Corp Yield since the close of the previous business day.
Date when the par held by the managing company on the instrument was last reported.
Par held by the company on the last reported date in USD by default when no conversion is requested.
Total amount that each corresponding underwriter has agreed to purchase pursuant to the offering.
Unique code representing the underwriter.
The long name of the underwriter.
Total shares that each corresponding underwriter has agreed to purchase pursuant to the agreement.
Date the asset was issued via an auction process. Used for U.S. Treasury and agency securities.

For securities with initial placement via underwriting, this is the pricing or trade date, i.e. the date on which terms of issuance are agreed upon between the Issuer and Underwriter. For securities with initial placement via an auction, this is the date on which the auction is announced. For securities placed via other methods, this could be any date when terms of issuance become available prior to the initial settlement date.
Lowest price (corresponding with the highest yield) of competitive bids accepted in the auction.
The interest quoted on a bond equivalent basis associated with the lowest price. Expressed as a percent.
The interest quoted on a bond equivalent yield basis associated with the average price. Expressed as a percent.
The interest quoted on a bond equivalent basis associated with the highest price. Expressed as a percent.
Calculated by the Modeller from information in the Offering Circular.
ID of Organisation involved in the insurance linked securities (either sponsor or modeller).
Name of the Organisation involved in the insurance linked securities (either sponsor or modeller).
The risk covered.
Description of the risk covered.
The location of the risk covered.
Description of the location of the risk covered.
The risk premium paid to the bondholder in addition to the reference rate.
Details the layer of insurance risk within a particular transaction.
Means of measuring when principal impairment will occur.
Description of means of measuring when principal impairment will occur.
Outstanding amount expressed in the currency of issue.
Effective date for outstanding amount change.

In case of an issuance, this is the price at which the public may purchase the individual tranche of the offered security, from the underwriter(s). In case of a redemption, price at which the issuer redeemed the individual tranche of the security. Expressed as a percentage of par.
Conversion Fractions.
Description of Conversion Fractions.
Conversion Interest.
Conversion Option Frequency.
Code indicating how the rate changes as a result of the conversion.
Description of Conversion Rate Type.
Conversion RIC.
Conversion Terms End Date.
Conversion Terms Start Date.
Code indicating the type of security before and after the conversion.
Description of Conversion Type.
Underlying asset price value at or above which the issuer has a call option right.
Code representing the method used to select a called bond in the event of a partial redemption.
Description of Hurdle Allocation.
Code representing the currency in which the bond is redeemed.
Description of the Hurdle Currency.
Time elapsed, measured in business or calendar days, in which the asset must exceed the hurdle value in order to trigger the hurdle.
Hurdle Duration Description.
Code representing the period during which conditions for the hurdle apply.
Start date from which the redemption price applies as part of the call hurdle.
Number of days notice the issuer is required to give in the event that the hurdle is exceeded and the issuer elects to call the bond.
Description of the Hurdle Notice.
Code representing the period of notice between the issuer’s declaration of redemption and the actual redemption.
Maximum period after the last day that the hurdle duration condition has been met before the issuer has to give notice of redemption.
Description of the Hurdle Period Description.
Code representing (along with hurdle days value) the maximum amount of time after crossing a hurdle before the issuer must declare redemption.
Code indicating what price should be used for the call hurdle.
Price at which the bond will be redeemed.
Code indicating how the bond will be called.
Description of the Hurdle Redemption Description.
Code representing how the hurdle value is expressed.
Description of the Hurdle Type.
Code representing categories of events that may effect the terms and conditions of a convertible security.
The number of shares that a holder receives for each security converted pursuant to the conversion option.
Price paid per share to acquire the underlying common stock.
Upper reset limit and maximum amount by which the new price must be more than the existing or refix reference price in order to trigger the refix. Expressed as a price, for example, EUR 1.
Lower reset limit and minimum amount by which the new price must be less than the existing or refix reference price in order to trigger the refix. Expressed as a price, for example, EUR 1.
Code representing the refix type.
Description of the Refix Type.

Price used to determine whether the underlying asset price has shifted enough to warrant a change in the conversion price. A large enough change in the underlying asset price from the reference price triggers a change in the conversion price.

Defines whether the refixed conversion price will be at any premium to the average stock price over which the refixed conversion price is fixed. Refixed premium is usually zero, but is sometimes the same as the original premium at issues.
Code indicating whether refix conditions run on business days or calendar days.
Number of days for which the refix conditions must be met prior to setting the date.
Description of the Refix Period.
Minimum to which the conversion price can be refixed. Expressed as a percentage of the prevailing conversion price.
Date for which the refix conversion price becomes effective.
Code representing the currency in which the reset limit is denominated.
Description of the Refix Currency.
Maximum to which the conversion price can be refixed.
Currency code of the conversion price on convertible bonds.
Currency name of the conversion price on convertible bonds.
The date from which the data in the record is effective (inclusive).

Code indicating the status of the terms of the issue during the initial phase. Convertibles are announced to the market before the terms are fully determined (commonly the coupon and conversion premium are often not yet fixed).
Convertibles are unusual in that a single set of economic terms may be associated with multiple tranches, which indicate differing status or trading restrictions.

Code representing the effective currency of the asset that underlies the convertible. In most cases, this will be the currency of the asset into which the bond converts. However, in the case of a convertible that converts into an A/GDR, the base currency will be that of the local share which is the basis of the A/GDR.
The aggregate (including any green shoe) size of the issue expressed in USD where necessary using an FX rate contemporary to the announcement date.
The aggregate (including any green shoe) size of the issue expressed in EUR where necessary using an FX rate contemporary to the announcement date.
A Y/N flag indicating if the bonds principal currency is different from that of the underlying asset.
Set to true if, instead of redeeming, the bondholder is required to convert the bond into a predetermined amount of underlying stock.
The RIC of the asset into which the instrument converts. When the underlying is a basket then this column contains the value “Basket.”
Indicates the major convertible exchangeable type. (i.e. Exchangeable or Convertible).
Indicates the major sub type of the issue (specifically, Convertible, Preference Share or Mandatory).
Indicates the common name of the underlying asset.
Indicates how remaining accrued interest is handled if conversion takes place between interest payment dates.
Contingency conversion leg number.
Date the conversion rights expire.
Indicates the exercise style of the conversion option.
Indicates the time period during which the conversion may occur.

Identifies the segment for which a specific set of convertible terms are contained. Different conversion options will also be represented under different leg numbers. For example a bond with a mandatory convertible option might also have a holder’s option to convert.
Indicates who has the option to convert.
Indicates how the underlying record is settled at conversion.
Date that corresponds with the effective conversion rate.
The RIC of the asset into which the instrument converts. When the underlying is a basket then this column contains the value “Basket”.

This is the ISO currency code of the underlying asset. This can be time consuming to extract from the convert_terms/sched/underlying_xref tables to it's replicated in the convert_def table to allow for timely access as this is one of the characteristics used in the convertible guides in Eikon.
This is the currency name of the underlying asset.
Upon conversion some bonds will not convert into a whole number of shares. In these cases, an auxiliary cash payment is made to the bondholder in lieu of the fractional shares.
Currency code in which the fractional payment amount is denominated.
Currency name in which the fractional payment amount is denominated.
The rate of exchange between the underlying asset and the bond in the manner indicated by the forex exchange rate description.
The price paid per share to acquire the underlying asset.
The amount of the underlying asset that the bondholder will receive per par amount at conversion. The formula is: Conversion Ratio = Par Amount/Conversion Price.

Code representing categories of events that may effect the terms and conditions of a convertible security. BSK: Change in Underlying Asset Qty for RIC; CAR: Change in Conversion Asset RIC; CCA: Change in Conversion Asset; CCC: Change in Conversion Price Currency; CCI: Change in Conversion Asset ID; CCP: Change in Conversion Price; CCR: Change in Conversion Ratio; CFX: Change in FX Rate; CPA: Change in Par Amount; CPE: Change in Conversion Period End Date; CPR: Change in Conversion Price and Ratio; CPS: Change in Conversion Period Start Date; CUA: Change in Underlying Asset; CUC: Change in Underlying Currency; ERE: Redenomination; INI: Initial Convertible Values.
Date on which the event occurred.
Description of the forex exchange rate.
The lower end of the conversion ratio range for DEC style mandatory convertibles.
The upper end of the conversion ratio range for DEC style mandatory convertibles.
The lower end of the conversion price range for DEC style mandatory convertibles.
The upper end of the conversion price range for DEC style mandatory convertibles.
A unit of reference for the conversion ratio, it is normally the minimum denomination of the bond.
Contingency conversion leg number.
Equity price type description.
If the trigger level changes periodically this is the value of the increment.
Period when the trigger level changes.
The number of days that comprise the sample period out of which the sample days are taken.
The number of days that the equity trigger has to exceed the trigger value in order to trigger.
The value of the equity trigger.
A Y/N flag indicating if the equity trigger condition is a knock-in type.
Once the premium trigger condition is met, this defines the number of days for which the bond is convertible.
Once the premium trigger condition is met, this defines the number of days before the holder can convert the bond.
The premium level at and below which the premium condition triggers.
The number of days that comprise the premium sample period out of which the sample days are taken.
The number of days that the premium trigger has to exceed the trigger value to trigger.
The rating that comprises the first rating trigger.
The rating that comprises the second rating trigger.
The rating that comprises the third rating trigger.
Logic representing the multiple rating trigger logic.
The rating agency code of the first contingent conversion rating trigger condition.
The rating agency code of the second contingent conversion rating trigger condition.
The rating agency code of the third contingent conversion rating trigger condition.
The rating agency name of the first contingent conversion rating trigger condition.
The rating agency name of the second contingent conversion rating trigger condition.
The rating agency name of the third contingent conversion rating trigger condition.
The maximum correction to the quantity defined by the compensation method in the threshold period.
The cash threshold as defined at issue.
The cash threshold corrected for corporate action on the underlying stock.
The annualized yield threshold.
The earnings per share threshold.
The last date on which the dividend protection terms ends being applicable.
Method by which the amount of compensation is calculated.
The minimum change to the quantity described by the compensation method.
The previous dividend threshold, expressed as the percentage increase in annualized dividend, required in order to trigger the dividend protection clause.
The first date on which the dividend protection terms starts being applicable.
Method representing how the four types of thresholds are used in combination.
The period during which the threshold is measured.
This defines the way in which the bondholder is compensated.
Underlying asset price value at or above which the issuer has a call option right.
Accretion method.
The rate at which the redemption price accretes. Expressed as an annualized rate for compounding accretion types and a daily amount for linear types.
Code representing the method used to select a called bond in the event of a partial redemption.
Description of hurdle allocation.
Code representing the currency in which the bond is redeemed.
Description of the hurdle currency.
Time elapsed, measured in business or calendar days, in which the asset must exceed the hurdle value in order to trigger the hurdle.
Description of hurdle duration.
Code representing the period during which conditions for the hurdle apply.
Start date from which the redemption price applies as part of the call hurdle.
The end date from which the redemption price applies as part of the call hurdle.
The redemption price at the end of the soft call period.
Number of days notice the issuer is required to give in the event that the hurdle is exceeded and the issuer elects to call the bond.
Description of the Hurdle Notice.
Code representing the period of notice between the issuer’s declaration of redemption and the actual redemption.
Maximum period after the last day that the hurdle duration condition has been met before the issuer has to give notice of redemption.
Description of hurdle period.
Code representing (along with hurdle days value) the maximum amount of time after crossing a hurdle before the issuer must declare redemption.
Code indicating what price should be used for the call hurdle.
Price at which the bond will be redeemed.
Code indicating how the bond will be called.
Description of the Hurdle Redemption Description.
Code representing how the hurdle value is expressed.
Description of the hurdle type.
Upper reset limit and maximum amount by which the new price must be more than the existing or refix reference price in order to trigger the refix. Expressed as a price, for example, EUR 1.
Lower reset limit and minimum amount by which the new price must be less than the existing or refix reference price in order to trigger the refix. Expressed as a price, for example, EUR 1.
Accretion method. For compound methods, this includes the compounding frequency.
The rate at which the redemption price accretes. Expressed as an annualized rate for compounding accretion types and a daily amount for linear types.
Last date on which the offered security can be redeemed for a given period at an indicated price.
The call price at the end of the call period. For non-accreting call end price will equal call start price. The call price is quoted as percent of face value.
First date on which the offered security can be redeemed for a given period at an indicated price.
Price at which the offered security can be redeemed for a given period. Expressed as a percentage of principal amount.
Current amount outstanding in local currency.
Current amount outstanding in local currency.
The date that the issue is first announced to the market.
Text description of the Asset.
Unique identifier for Asset which is part of Underlying.
Actual value of the Asset Key Type.

Reuters generated unique key that identifies the asset in terms of a RIC (Reuters Instrument Code, used by all Reuters databases), PID (Primary_ID, created by DBS) or PILC (Primary Issue Level Code, created by MRD.
The RIC (Reuters Instrument Code) for the underlying asset.
Stored in a free text format, defines the formula used for conversion of the Asset.
Determines what unit of measurement such as Currency, Percentage or Shares is associated with the underlying asset.
In a basket, this indicates the percentage or the number of shares, as described by Basket_Weighting_Type, of the initial basket value represented by each Asset in the basket.
Identifies the type of data in Basket_Weighting, for instance percent or shares.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that can be ‘called’ back from the holder by the issuer.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have been called by the issuer.
Reports the actual conversion price.
Currency in which the Asset prices.
Defines the conversion ratio.
Currency that the investor would receive if the Underlying is settled in cash.
Describes in detail any limit on the rate of conversion of the debt.
Indicates whether the conversion is mandatory, happens at the option of the issuer, or the holder.
System generated unique key for a given set of conversion terms for a given convertible.
Indicates whether this is a ratio, price, complex term, or refix.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have conversion features into another security.
The ISO code for the market in which the debt was originally issued.
The (annualized) rate of interest paid by the bond in the current period.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have issue-level credit ratings.
Date from which accrued interest is calculated on newly issued debt instruments. For zero coupon bonds, it is the date on which yield starts compounding.
Combined with conversion_term_id, uniquely identifies the Date Range applied to the Conversion Terms.
Date Seasoned.
Day Count used for accrued interest calculations.
Day Conversion.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have missed an interest payment and are in default.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds whose compound interest will be paid at maturity.
When there are multiple Underlying records associated with the convertible, this field defines who decides which of the Underlyings will be delivered.
Dilution Protection Type.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify zero coupon bonds initially priced well below par and pay interest by returning the face amount of the bond to the bond holder.
Date associated with the Amount Outstanding.
Dual Currency.
Emu Notes.
End Date.
End Month.
Determines, when one cash flow is paid at the end of the month, whether the next cash flow is also paid on the end of the month or on a date with the same day value as the first cash flow.
Exercise Type.
The date to which the interest accrues for the first coupon period. The first coupon payment is assumed to occur on the same day.

This describes whether the coupon payment is a rate that changes based on an index value, or a fixed percent of principal. The absence of a coupon, i.e. a zero coupon bond, would be indicated by a coupon of zero.
Frequency Code.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have been funged into another security.
FX Rate.
FX Rate Type.
Geographic Sector.
Geographic Sector Code.
Global Issue.
Has RICS.
Code that indicates the applicable market holiday schedule.
Holiday ConV.
Indicates if the bond has its principal payment(s) tied to an index (typically inflation indices).
Industry Sector.
Code of industrial classification for the issuer of the bond (only alphabetic classification codes shown, non MSCI).
Interest On Conversion Type.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds whose non-compound interest will be paid at maturity.
Currency in which the Coupons of the bond is denominated.
Interest Currency.
Is Callable.
Is Coupon Bearing.
Is Exchange Listed.
The country (or geographic unit) in which the organisation is registered for tax purposes.
Issue Amount.
Code for currency in which the security is denominated at launch.
Issue Currency Code.
Issue Status.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify Italian CCT floating rate notes, and the BOT bills whose auction results used to calculate its coupon.
The date on which the last full coupon payment is made. This will be equal to the maturity date if the coupon payment cycle coincides with the principal repayment.
Latest Rating.
Latest Rating Date.
Latest Rating Rank.
Latest Rating SP Equivalent.
Latest Rating Source.
Latest Rating Source Code.
The date on which the bond will be redeemed completely.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have been matured.
The minimum denomination refers to the smallest amount that an investor is required to purchase. For example, the minimum denomination on US treasury bonds is $10,000.
Refers to the smallest increment in to which to bond has been issued. The minimum denomination plus the denomination increment determine the lot sizes that are available.
A grouping of Database views that provide criteria search functionality, such as the ability to find all stocks on a particular exchange.
Indicates whether the bond has a variable rate coupon.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have coupon payment frequencies that change over time.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have complex terms and conditions.
Amount of notice given prior to conversion.
Type of days referenced in Notice_Period, such as Business or Calendar or Trading.
Contains the number of common shares outstanding at time of issue. Only applies to an Underlying of a single equity.
Two character code uniquely identifying a bond.
A system generated key that uniquely identifies the market organisation.
Organisation Type Code.
The original amount issued in local currency.
The date the bond was issued.
The price at issuance of the bond.
Spread in basis points from which the issue was originally priced with reference to market benchmark.
The Yield to maturity at issuance of the bond.
Par amount of the convertible.
Specifies the full name of the ultimate parent organisation.
A system generated key that uniquely identifies the ultimate parent organisation which owns the majority of the issuing entity.
Definition Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that can be paid for in installments.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that have no stated maturity date.
Indicates that instead of coupon being paid in cash, it is paid with similar baby bonds.
Reports, if any, the percent premium to the convertible debt at launch.
Code for currency in which the Principal of the bond is denominated.
Currency in which the Principal of the bond is denominated.

Indicates the percentage of par value of principal paid on the Maturity Date. 1) Adjustments to the redemption value due to index-linked provisions do not affect the value of this element. 2) Exceptions to the definition are made for securities whose mark.
Indicates whether the price quotation for the bond is inclusive (dirty) or exclusive (clean) of accrued interest.
Indicates if the database has bond prospectus on file.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that are private placements.
Indicator (Y/N) to signify bonds that can be ‘put’ back to the issuer by the holder.
Used to record 144A and Reg S related details.
Contains codes which contain information on the payout priority of the issue in the event of bankruptcy of the issuer.
Rule specifying the number of business/calendar days after trade settlement takes place.
The period within which settlement from delivery of the debt instrument to the receipt of the underlying asset.
Type of days referenced in settlement_period, such as Business or Calendar or Trading.
Indicates the way in which a contract settles, i.e. whether in 'Cash' or 'Physical' form.
Indicates if the bond has a sinking fund or purchase fund provision.
Indicates whether the bond is subject to early redemption upon the occurrence of events and/or at option prices that are not predictable.
The Start date for the Date Range applied to the Conversion Terms.

Details any protection available to the issuer and investor if the stock is bought back. Usually deals with MandA activity to prevent leaving the investor with a low coupon bond and no equity involvement.
A system generated number that uniquely identifies an individual security.
TI ID.
A very short (up to 6 character) name for the Issuer.
Defines what type of a financial instrument class the underlying asset belongs to.
Reports foreign exchange rate fixed ahead of time for the conversion.
Indicates whether the forex rate is Base to Asset or Asset to Base.
System generated number used to uniquely identify the Underlying.
Code for rule to determine the value date with respect to settlement or trade date. The value date is the date from which the buyer of a bond accrues interest.
Rule to determine the value date with respect to settlement or trade date. The value date is the date from which the buyer of a bond accrues interest.
Indicator [Y/N] to signify if warrants are attached to the bond.
Rule, expressed in number of days before the coupon period, when the bond goes ex-dividend.
Ex-Dividend Conversion.
The face value of a security.
The initial rate at which earnings are distributed to holders of the offered security.
This is the last regular annual dividend paid to the stockholder by the company. Expressed in currency of issue.
The total amount that a stockholder is entitled to receive from the distribution of assets in the event of liquidation.
Maximum number of shares of a class or type of security which may be issued by the registrant, as authorized by the articles of incorporation of the registrant.
A y/n flag indicating whether there is an anti-takeover provision requiring more than a 51% vote.
A y/n flag indicating whether dividends may accumulate if not declared.
A y/n flag indicating whether the holder has cumulative voting privileges.
A y/n flag that, if set to "y", indicates that large share holders do not have the same rights as smaller share holders.
A y/n flag indicating whether shareholder dividends may be automatically reinvested in additional shares of the company's capital stock.
A y/n flag indicating whether the company plans to pay any cash dividends in the near future, or has a policy of paying cash dividends on, the security convertible into.
A y/n flag that, if set to "y", indicates that the securities authorized by the company entitle the holder with the right to receive dividends.
A y/n flag that indicating whether the holder is entitled to share in the distribution of assets in the event of liquidation.
A y/n flag indicating whether existing shareholders have the right to purchase shares of a new issue before it is offered to the public.
A y/n flag indicating whether the securities authorized by the registrant entitle the holder to vote in shareholders' meetings
Benchmark bond asset id.
Benchmark bond ISIN code.
Date on which the asset became a benchmark security.
Date on which the asset is no longer considered a benchmark security. If superseded by another security, the "end date" is set to the calendar day before the "begin date" of the successor record.
